title: How I note authors: Alexey, Shmalko url: https://www.alexeyshmalko.com/how-i-note/ tags  ğŸ“Org-roam ğŸ“Zettelkasten Method    highlights    ç§ã¯ã‚ˆãæœ¬ã‚„è«–æ–‡ã‚„ãƒˆãƒ¼ã‚¯ã‚’ã‚¤ãƒ³ãƒ—ãƒƒãƒˆã™ã‚‹.Webè¨˜äº‹ã¯å½¢éª¸ãªã®ã§èª­ã¾ãªã„.     I mostly read books, research papers, and I watch talks. I read less and less articles onlineâ€”I find most to be too shallow (compared to books), too narrow (dealing with specific technical issues rather than long-living ideas), and not worth taking notes on. (Though there are great ones!)
 èª­ã¿ãªãŒã‚‰æ‰‹ã§ãƒ¢ãƒ¬ã‚¹ã‚­ãƒ³ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã‚’å–ã‚‹ã‚ˆ.æœ¬ã«ç·šã¯å¼•ã‹ãªã„ã‘ã©.     While reading, I take notes on paper (small Moleskine notebook). I donâ€™t highlight.
 ãƒ¢ãƒ¬ã‚¹ã‚­ãƒ³ã‹ã‚‰ã®æ–‡çŒ®ãƒ¡ãƒ¢ã‚‚Orgzlyã‹ã‚‰ã®èµ°ã‚Šæ›¸ãã®ãƒ¡ãƒ¢ã‚‚ï¼Œã‚¦ã‚§ãƒ–ã‚­ãƒ£ãƒ—ãƒãƒ£ã—ãŸè¨˜äº‹ã‚‚å…¨éƒ¨Inboxã«ã„ã‚Œã‚‹.     Once a day I process my inbox: literature notes from notebook, fleeting notes, tasks, and articles from org file.
 è¨˜äº‹ã¯(book/article/paper/talk)ã«åˆ†é¡ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹. org-ref, ivy-bibtex, org-roam-bibtexã‚’ä½¿ã£ã¦org-fileã§ç®¡ç†ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹.     I maintain a file per resource (book/article/paper/talk).
  I manage my bibliography with org-ref, ivy-bibtex, and org-roam-bibtex.
 https://www.alexeyshmalko.com/biblio/
Permanent Noteã¯å†åˆ©ç”¨å¯èƒ½ãªå½¢ã§è¨˜è¿°ã™ã‚‹ã®ãŒãƒŸã‚½.ã‹ã‚“ãŸã‚“ã«ä»–ã®æ–‡è„ˆã«åŸ‹ã‚è¾¼ã‚ã‚‹ã®ã§.     a note describes one idea only. This makes notes reusableâ€”focused ideas are easy to apply in different context.
 Structure notesã¯ Table of Contents(TOC)ã§ï¼Œã„ã‚ã‚†ã‚‹Map of Contents(MOC)ã . Topicã”ã¨ã«ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã‚’ã¾ã¨ã‚ã‚‹ã“ã¨ãŒç›®çš„.     Structure notes are kind of a table of contents for Zettelkasten (some call them Map of Contents notes)â€”they help me group notes on a topic.
 Structure Notesã«ã¯ï¼Œ$ã‚’prefixã§ã¤ã‘ã¦ã„ã‚‹.ã‚°ãƒ«ãƒ¼ãƒ—ãŒå°ã•ã‘ã‚Œã°ç›¸äº’ãƒªãƒ³ã‚¯ã•ã›ã‚Œã°ã„ã„.ãŸã ã‚°ãƒ«ãƒ¼ãƒ—ã‹å¤§ãããªã£ã¦ããŸã‚‰$ã‚’prefixã¨ã™ã‚‹ãƒˆãƒ”ãƒƒã‚¯ã‚’ä½œæˆã™ã‚Œã°ã„ã„.è‡¨æ©Ÿå¿œå¤‰ã«.     When the number of notes in a group is small, you donâ€™t need structure notesâ€”you can just cross-link all relevant notes. But when the number of notes grows, it stops being practicalâ€”it is useful to have an overview note.
  My structure notes usually start with the Â§ prefix.
 Tag Noteã¨ã„ã†ã®ã‚’ä½œæˆã—ãŸ.ã“ã‚Œã¯"List of xxxx"ã¨ã„ã†ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒˆãƒ«ã§, #xxxã¨ã„ã†ã‚¨ã‚¤ãƒªã‚¢ã‚¹ã§è¡¨ç¾ã™ã‚‹.ã“ã®Tag Noteã«$ã§ã¯ã˜ã¾ã‚‹Topicã‚’ãƒªãƒ³ã‚¯ã•ã›ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã§ï¼Œãƒãƒƒã‚¯ãƒªãƒ³ã‚¯ã‚’ã‚¹ãƒƒã‚­ãƒªã¾ã¨ã‚ã‚‹ã“ã¨ãŒã§ããŸ.     I created â€œList of somethingâ€ pages and aliased them to â€œ#something.â€ Then I could tag programming languages with #programming-language and ideas about programming languages with Â§ Programming Language.This helps to keep the list of backlinks clean.
 Roam Researchã®æ…£ç¿’ã§Placeholder notesã¨ã„ã†ã‚‚ã®ãŒã‚ã‚‹.ã“ã‚Œã¯å˜èªã‚’ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒˆãƒ«ã«ã—ã¦ä¸­èº«ãŒç©ºç™½ãªãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã§ãƒãƒƒã‚¯ãƒªãƒ³ã‚¯ã‚’é›†ã‚ã‚‹ã“ã¨ãŒç›®çš„ã®ãƒ¢ãƒ.ã—ã‹ã—ã‚ãŸã—ã¯ã“ã‚Œã‚’ã¤ã‹ã‚ãªã„.ã“ã‚“ãªã‚‚ã®ã¯å½¹ã«ç«‹ãŸãªã„ã—ï¼Œãƒªãƒ³ã‚¯ãŒå¿…è¦ãªã‚‰ç›´æ¥ã¯ã‚Œ(ã¨ã¾ã§ã¯è¨€ã£ã¦ãªã„).     I donâ€™t do that. I find placeholders quite useless. I rarely filled them, and most of them just kept living with a single link. So I deleted all placeholders I had.
 Roam Resarchã®åˆ¥ã®æ…£ç¿’ã®ã‚ˆã†ã«å˜èªã‚’å…¨éƒ¨ãƒªãƒ³ã‚¯ã™ã‚‹ã‚ˆã†ãªWikiã®ä½¿ã„æ–¹ã¯ã—ãªã„.æ€æ…®æ·±ããƒªãƒ³ã‚¯ã‚’çµã¶ã‚“ã .programmingã¨ã„ã†å˜èªãŒã‚ã£ãŸã‹ã‚‰ã£ã¦ã‚„ãŸã‚‰ã‚ã£ãŸã‚‰programmingã¨ã„ã†å˜èªã§ãƒªãƒ³ã‚¯ã—ã¾ãã‚‰ãªã„.ã“ã‚Œã‚’é¡Œã—ã¦Mindful Linkingã¨ã„ã†.     Another practice common in Roam Research is linking every word that you happen to have a note on.
  I try to be more deliberate with linking
 ãƒãƒ¼ãƒˆã®ç¨®é¡ã¯çµµæ–‡å­—ã‚’ãƒ—ãƒ¬ãƒ•ã‚£ãƒƒã‚¯ã‚¹ã«ã¤ã‘ã¦ãƒ‡ã‚£ãƒ¬ã‚¯ãƒˆãƒªã”ã¨åŒºåˆ¥ã—ã¦ã‚‹ã‚ˆ.     /: permanent â€œknowledgeâ€ notes (ğŸ“) /biblio: bibliographic (literature) notes (ğŸ“–) /posts: posts intended for others (ğŸ–‹) /life: random notes about myself and my small side projects. Not published /life/journal: a place for journaling and my daily notes /: work-related notes. To be deleted when I quit the job. Not published
 Literature Noteã¨Permanent Noteã¯åŒºåˆ¥ã™ã‚‹ï¼Œæ··ãœãŸã‚‰å±é™º.ãªãœãªã‚‰Literature Noteã¯ã‚ãŸã—ã®Ideaã§ãªã„.    projectã”ã¨ã«ãƒ‡ã‚£ãƒ¬ã‚¯ãƒˆãƒªã‚’ã‚ã‘ã‚Œã°ã¾ã¨ã‚ã¦ã‚¢ãƒ¼ã‚«ã‚¤ãƒ–ã§ãã‚‹.ãã—ã¦lifelongãªã‚ãŸã—ã®ãƒ¡ãƒ¢ã¯Lifeã«ãƒ©ãƒ³ãƒ€ãƒ ã«çªã£è¾¼ã‚“ã§ã‚‹ã‚ˆ.     In general, it makes sense to create a slip box for every project you have (test: are these notes useful after the project is done?). Job is an example of such a project, and I treat my life as an ultimate project.

In general, it makes sense to create a slip box for every project you have (test: are these notes useful after the project is done?).  ã‚ãŸã—ã¯éå»ã®ãƒ–ãƒ­ã‚°ã‚‚å…¨éƒ¨Slipboxã«ã¶ã¡è¾¼ã‚“ã .å¤§å¤‰ã ã£ãŸãŒæº€è¶³ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹.ãªãœãªã‚‰ã‹ã¤ã¦ã¯3ã¤ã‚‚ã‚µã‚¤ãƒˆãŒã‚ã£ãŸã‚“ã ã‚ˆï¼ã‚ã‚“ã©ãã•ã™ãã‚‹.å‹•ç‰©åœ’ã‹ã‚ˆ!    link: https://www.alexeyshmalko.com/merging-my-websites/
 Itâ€™s taxing to maintain a zoo of websites using different technologies, and it is even harder to build an audience for each separately (especially given they are just side projects).
 éå»ã®è¨˜äº‹ã¯ã™ã¹ã¦ãƒªãƒ€ã‚¤ãƒ¬ã‚¯ãƒˆã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹ã‹ã‚‰å•é¡Œãªã„.æ•°å¹´å¾Œã«å‰Šé™¤ã™ã‚‹.    All of the websites now redirect to this one Iâ€™ve managed to merge all paths, so all existing links redirect to the same posts on this website. Iâ€™ll shut down other websites in a year or two.
ãƒ•ã‚¡ã‚¤ãƒ«åã¯ã™ã¹ã¦ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒ ã‚¹ã‚¿ãƒ³ãƒ—ã«ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹.ãªãœãªã‚‰ã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒˆãƒ«ã¯ã—ã‚‡ã£ã¡ã‚…ã†å¤‰æ›´ã™ã‚‹ã‹ã‚‰.ãã—ã¦ãã‚Œã‚’ãã®ã¾ã¾URLã®è¨˜äº‹IDã«ã‚‚ã¤ã‹ã£ã¦ã„ã‚‹.     Now I use timestamp-based filenames (e.g., 20210613055225.org), and thatâ€™s what you can see in URLs.

shadowban.euã«ã‚ˆã‚‹ã‚·ãƒ£ãƒ‰ã‚¦ãƒãƒ³ã®åˆ†é¡    æœ¬å®¶ã‚µã‚¤ãƒˆã¯ã™ã§ã«é–‰é–æ¸ˆã¿. 4ã¤ã«è¦åˆ¶ã‚’åˆ†é¡ã—ã¦ã„ã‚‹.
 Search Suggestion Ban  This type of ban causes an account to not populate search suggestions and people search results when it is searched for while being logged out. Twitter seems to take tie strength or a similar metric into account. While an account may be suggested to users you are strongly tied to, it may not be shown to others.   Search Ban  This type of ban causes your tweets to be hidden from the search results entirely, no matter whether the quality filter is turned on or off. This behavior includes hashtags as well. This type of ban seems to be temporally limited for active accounts.   Ghost Ban  This is what is referred to as conventional shadowban or thread banning as well. It comprises a search ban while threads are completely ripped apart by hiding reply tweets of the affected user to others. Everything will look perfectly normal to the affected user but many others will not be able to see reply tweets of the affected user at all. Reasons for this ban include behavior like excessive tweeting or following. Again, this type of ban seems to be temporally limited for active accounts.   Reply Deboosting  If Twitter’s signals determine that an account might engage in harmful behavior, Twitter hides their replies behind a barrier and only loads them when “Show more replies” is clicked. This behavior is personalized, i.e. Twitter does not hide the tweets of accounts you follow. We therefore use an unbiased reference account without followings in order to determine whether tweets within a thread can be retrieved without clicking “Show more replies” from its view. In some cases, Twitter classifies accounts as offensive. In this case, replies are hidden behind a second barrier within the “Show more replies” section. The outcome of this test may depend on the conversation which we found one of your tweets in. For testing, we take your latest reply tweet that is not within a conversation you started. Note that test results are cached for a short period of time. A failure to test is neither a positive nor a negative test result. This test relies on some conditions that are not fulfilled by all accounts. In some cases, we cannot test for purely technical reasons.    https://github.com/shadowban-eu
